item.title: Small Business Idea: AI Narratologist: Turning Books into Structured Data
item.content:encoded: The Literary Data Gold Rush We stand at the precipice of a new era where the vast, unstructured ocean of human literature—from ancient texts to modern thrillers—can be transformed into actionable, queryable data. Forget simply summarizing; imagine a tool that extracts the very essence of narrative, connecting dots, revealing patterns, and building comprehensive knowledge graphs from any written work. This isn't just about reading; it's about truly understanding and analyzing literature at scale. ### Brief description of the idea Develop an AI-powered service that takes unstructured literary text (books, articles, research papers, scripts, etc.) and transforms it into structured data formats like JSON or a conceptual knowledge graph. This involves identifying entities (characters, locations, events, themes), their attributes, and the explicit or implicit relationships between them, all via large language models (LLMs). ### Core Value Proposition Liberate hidden insights and accelerate research, writing, and understanding by converting any literary corpus into queryable, machine-readable datasets. Empower users to visualize narrative structures, track thematic development, compare character interactions across works, or rapidly extract specific factual information, transcending manual reading and note-taking limitations. ### Target Customers * Academic Researchers & Students: For literary analysis, historical research, comparative studies, and thesis preparation across extensive bodies of work. * Authors & Screenwriters: For world-building consistency, character arc mapping, plot structure analysis, and in-depth research for new projects. * Publishing Houses & Content Strategists: For analyzing trends, audience preferences, and cross-referencing intellectual property assets. * Data Journalists & Fact-Checkers: To rapidly extract and verify information from reports, historical documents, or public statements. ### Minimum Viable Product (MVP) Scope (Implementable in a day) "Character Interaction Extractor" The goal is to demonstrate the core capability of transforming text into structured data focusing on a highly relatable literary aspect: character relationships. Here's how: 1. Simple Web Interface: A single page with a text area or file upload (.txt only) where a user can paste or upload a short story excerpt or a chapter from a book. 2. LLM Integration: On submission, send the text to a readily available LLM API (e.g., OpenAI GPT-4, Anthropic Claude, or even a local open-source model). The prompt instructs the LLM to: * Identify all named characters within the provided text. * For each character, identify other characters they explicitly interact with or mention. * Briefly describe the nature of that interaction/mention. * Crucially, request the output in a strict JSON format (e.g., [{"character": "Name", "interactions": [{"with": "Other Name", "description": "Action/Description"}, ...]}]). 3. Display Output: Parse the JSON response from the LLM and display it directly on the webpage, perhaps prettified. No fancy graph visualization needed for this MVP; the raw, structured data is the value proposition here. This MVP immediately proves the concept: unstructured literary text goes in, structured, queryable data comes out, ready for further analysis or visualization. Focus on making this single extraction type robust and reliable.
